title: Why is the Russian song 'Katyusha' so popular in Russia? - Quora

response.answer_text: The premise of the question is wrong. Katyusha isn’t popular in Russia, it’s popular in the whole world. See Daniel Ptashny's answer to What popular songs have been translated into the most number of languages? Besides for being a beautiful song with beautiful words, I think the message of the song is a very powerful one and one that speaks to many people. It’s a message of hope and sacrifice, of love and a deep sense of mission. For contrast, let’s examine two other songs with similar content: Erika in German, and another one of my favorites - Smuglyanka. A soldiers morale will definitely go up when he remembers his Erika back at home, but it’s more of a personal thing. Besides for the fact that this song is lacking her side, she encouraging him; in addition when he’s thinking about Erika it’s only about her. The mission is important, but only as secondary to her; or maybe even only for her, to protect her. The mission in itself is of secondary importance, if at all. These aren’t the words of the song, but it’s the feeling I get out of it. Smuglyanka is the polar opposite. Here, the Smuglyanka is reprimanding the boy for flirting while he should be with the Partisans at the front. Sort of like saying “no more monkey business, get to work”. Although joyous, it does have a damn serious message. The thing is, it doesn’t seem like the boy really gets it, he’s a bit reluctant. This is reflected - in my understanding - in the lines “В том обиду я увидел, Что с собой не позвала” (“I was hurt that she didn’t invite me to come with her”). All in all, it’s a powerful song, but it ain’t Katyusha. This starts off joyous, as both are on their posts and happy with it. I don’t mean that each is happy where they are, Katyusha is also happy that the warrior is holding his post, the fact that they’re far away doesn’t affect their feelings for one another one bit. In fact, it only makes it greater; not in a sense of longing, but more in a sense of pride. How goes the last line? “Пусть он землю бережет родную, а любовь Катюша сбережет” (“let him guard the motherland, and I will guard the love). To sum it up, the other two songs are about longing (which may be a boost of morale or may be a disturbance, but that isn’t the point). But Katyusha talks about mutual sense of responsibility. I also tend to get the feeling that Katyusha has a subtle message of hope the other ones are lacking, but I can’t pinpoint where exactly.

Actually, the song “Katyusha” was written before the World War II, but it became very popular during the war and it is now viewed as a “folk song”. It is a beautiful song with a simple upbeat tune. The tune is easy to sing, even for children. For example, my son, who is ten years old, learned it a few years ago and can still sing a few verses. The author of the lyrics Mikhail Isakovskiy (Михаил Васильевич Исаковский) also wrote many other still popular songs, like “Oi, tsvetet kalina” (Ой, цветет калина”), and “Kakim ty byl, takim ostalsya”(Каким ты был, таким остался). Th composer, Matvej Blunter (Матвей Исаакович Блантер) is well know for his war-time marches, but he is also the author of some romances, like Zhdi menya” ( Жди меня), “V gorodskom sadu igraet” (В городском саду играет). This last one was my grandmothers’s favourite. There are lots of great songs written about (or during) the war. Many of them are still popular because they are just that good. And catchy. I am quite sure that not-quite-sober company of youngsters that sang “Katyusha” under my window did it without thinking about war or weapons.
